One thing about the "logging of assertions" is reporting on the Actual/Obse=
rved results. I work at a company that makes Medical Devices. The FDA, as w=
e're told by QA, requires the deposition of all tests. So even Pass'ing tes=
ts must have their actual results reported on. We do this currently with ma=
nual/human tests.

If the report could say something like:
Test ID Status E=
xpected        Actual
123       Pass  Smith           Smith
456       Pass =
 Value > 10      12
789       Fail  Value =3D "abc"   xyz
...

This report =
would be stored (for many years) for audit purposes.

Now being a newbie, m=
aybe there is a way to do this I don't know about - but very useful.

Mark

> I have read car=
efully all the posts so far and I tend to agree with
> Robert. I am wonder =
whether I miss something important too.
> I want to be clear, so I will tak=
e one step backward. What is the MAIN
> purpose of JUnit? The answer is to =
be able to write AUTOMATIC unit
> test. Unit test should be written is the =
correct way, that is
> correctly design. This has nothing to do with loggin=
g. Making unit
> test AUTOMATIC contradict using logging.
> 
> <you can ski=
p the this paragraph>
> I want to step aside for a while. Let assume that y=
ou're not using
> JUnit at all and write small main function to test. I don=
't want to
> counter why you shouldn't do this, let focus on what tools you=
 do use
> in this approach. In the most cases you will add System.out both =
to
> the code and to the main. If you're using C++, for instance, you will
=
> use preprocessor to switch on or off these output to the console. More
> =
advance option will be to use logging mechanism and to change it
> configur=
ation depends on the environment your program run (that is to
> turn on man=
y of your log statement only in development). Everything is
> great until y=
our program is actually fails. Again, from the experience
> it is almost al=
ways the case that existing System.outs are not enough,
> that you need mor=
e information or you should add some more output
> early in the code. So, i=
n this point you have to option to run your
> program AGAIN with debugger o=
r to add more System.outs and to run it
> as is. In both cases it can be th=
e case that you should rerun your
> program again (if you use debugger you =
could simply not pointed out
> when some data changed and in the System.out=
 case you can figure out
> that you need more System.outs).
> 
> From the p=
aragraph above one should conclude that when one write unit
> test there is=
 2 different phases. First is to write them down in the
> hope that everyth=
ing will be ok (it doesn't mean, that you design
> should be poor or you sh=
ouldn't supply appropriate messages to assert
> statements etc) and the sec=
ond phase is to rerun your test if your
> test fails. Lets see how logging =
will help you.
> 
> In the first phase I see the only purpose using logs is=
 for 'sanity
> check' that is to ensure that you actually test what your th=
ink is you
> test. If you want to make something more than just 'sanity che=
ck' you
> should write unit test to your unit test, that is pretty silly.
>=
 Moreover, you need to make such 'sanity check' only when you actually
> wr=
ite this test.  For this purpose logging is appropriate approach, IMHO.
> 
=
> In the second phase, when you rerun your unit test when it fails, you
> s=
hould consider to add more assert statement and more clearly
> diagnostic m=
essages first. When you done and you don't see how to
> improve the design =
(recall I consider that design is correct) you can
> add log statement manu=
ally. But in this case they will not be part of
> new mechanism, because no=
 more asserts will be added. So this new
> feature will not be in use!
> 
>=
 Using logging in the assert statement ONLY for 'sanity check' is
> overkil=
l, I think. As for me I make such 'sanity check' in the
> following way. Fi=
rst of all, I use log4j MANUALLY that is as addition
> to JUnit asserts. Th=
ey don't duplicate what asserts does they supply
> additional information, =
such as what assertion was already done. In
> this case when assertion will=
 fail afterwards I can look on the log to
> see in what part of unit test i=
t happened and what tests passed. I go
> even further and use JDK 1.4 asser=
t statement to document
> precondition, postcondition and invariants both i=
n the code and in the
> unit test.
> 
> The bottom line is that I see the s=
ense using logs as a COMPLETION to
> the JUnit and only for 'sanity check'.=
 This use is not duplicates
> JUnit assert statements and could be written =
manually.
